title: Can I audition for a musical even if I'm not a good singer? - Quora

response.answer_text: YES! Look at some of the character actors in musicals, usually the “friend” of the star or some other fairly substantial role but is very comedic. Ado Annie in Oklahoma is an example. The stepsisters in Cinderella are another. Just know what you are trying out FOR and sing an appropriate song for the role (not from the musical you are auditioning for, but similar in range). These are parts that require great acting skills and usually a medium amount of vocal chops.

Sure, why not? If you don't pass the audition they don't throw you in jail for 6 months! ( They just humiliate you in front of everybody else! ) “You just pick your self up, dust your self off and start all over again"! I think most “Broadway” actors stink as singers! Who knows, you might make it big! ( If not after multiple rejections you might think about getting some lessons? Just a thought. )

How do you figure you can’t sing? Has some teacher actually stood in front of you and said, “You can’t sing?” That would be my first question. My long experience in music education has confirmed my belief that everyone can sing. You may not Met Opera or Broadway material, but you can sing! Any music experience you can gain by being in a musical will only benefit your voice. On the other hand, If, indeed, you cannot sing there are many ways to participate in a stage production without singing. I would strongly encourage you to audition or express an interest in working on the tech end of the production. Good luck to you . . . er . . . BREAK A LEG!

Original question: Should I audition for a musical if I can’t sing? I can’t sing (or dance) either, and yet I have auditioned for - and been in - musicals. However, I would say that in the last 10 years or so it’s begun to be much more difficult for those who can’t sing or dance to get cast in musicals. It used to be the case that for “character” parts, acting ability was more important - you could “act” your way through a song in character. The character was more important than the song. That is less the case now. More and more, producers want trained singers and dancers. That doesn’t mean you shouldn’t audition - being challenged is good for you, and any audition is an opportunity to do your job.

Sure. As long as you're not trying for a role that requires a singer play it, being able to sing clearly with good pitch and adequate volume should be enough. As someone else has said, there are often non-singing roles. But unless you're thinking of auditioning for a professional show, a good clear voice that can carry a tune should be fine for chorus. If you're worried at all, you could go for a couple of voice lessons just to have a good ear listen and offer suggestions. Good luck!

Yes, try out for an ensemble role or a featured role if you have dance experience. If it’s a school show I’m sure you’ll be cast and if you don’t then join a community theatre production. You don’t necessarily have to be an amazing singer to be in musicals! Please reach out if you have any more questions!!! Break a leg!!!!!
Musicals need singers, but also actors for the non-singing roles (especially older characters-but there IS age make-up), plus dancers, and techies. Theatre is a great experience.
